mlynaruvucen_book_part_j6ua: If you don't want to scrape the sanyther out of the barn and search the pits, do this. Make a pipe out of clay with some small holes in it. Take a pound of wine-stone, half a pound of salt, three times as much lime, and the urine of a man who likes to drink wine. Make a slurry of the materials and spread it inside the pipe. Leave it in the sun for three days and empty it on the fourth day. Then hang the pipe in the cellar and wait for the ice to grow. Then boil the sanyther in water, wine or better vinegar as you would a fish and strain it through a thick cloth. Let the crystals dry carefully.

If you don't want to scrape the saltpetre out of the sties or search in the pits, do this. Make a pipe out of clay with some small holes in it. Take a pound of tartaric acid, half a pound of salt, three times as much lime and the urine of a wine-drinker. Make a mash from the materials and spread it inside the pipe. Leave it in the sun for three days and empty it on the fourth day. Then hang the pipe in the cellar and wait for the nitre to grow. Then boil the saltpetre in water, wine or better vinegar as you would a fish and strain it through a thick cloth. Let the crystals dry properly.
mlynaruvucen_book_part_TyrL: <paragraph>Among the qualities of a true master of fire are: The warrior's godliness, for when he handles dust, he has his arch-enemy in his hands. He also maintains humility towards the world he walks day and night. He should, as a master, be able to read and write, otherwise the knowledge written in this book, whether it be distillation, separation or sublimation, cannot be retained in the mind. Only a man of prudence, honesty, kindness in word and deed will become a master. In particular, he must avoid drunkenness at any hour.</paragraph><newpage/>

natroskach_zapiskyfelcara_g76V: <paragraph>I didn't tell him that, of course. So I gave him some talk about the domes of Mars and the phases of the moon, so that it was clear that without a scholar of my capacity he would not prepare any miraculous concoction. I wonder when he'll come again.

natroskach_zapiskyfelcara_gCoE: <paragraph>Erazim the scribe was with me again. The fever had apparently subsided, but he demanded my tonic again. He said he was still coming back at night, which is not unusual, but my tonicum should not be given lightly. I therefore gave him another dose, but warned him that it was the last. He made a rather strange face and then proceeded to question me rather clumsily about the composition of the tonic.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Erazim the scribe was with me again. The fever had apparently subsided, but he demanded my tonic again. He said the fever keeps coming back at night, which is not unusual, but my tonicum should not be given lightly. I therefore gave him another dose, but warned him that it was the last. He made a rather strange face and then proceeded to question me rather clumsily about the composition of the tonic.</paragraph>

The decoction is prepared from boiled wine, three parts of stinging nettle, two parts of grated ginger and one part of elder leaves.

natroskach_zapiskyfelcara_UNSA: <paragraph>Once again there was Mr. Chamberlain Ulrich, but this time he did not come to plead with me, but on the contrary came running with a plea. His stomach is bothering him. After a short examination I immediately knew that he was suffering from a stomach ulcer, but I had not forgotten the unprecedented humiliation he had caused me, so instead of a professional diagnosis, I muttered something about Galen and the body juices, threw up my hands helplessly and escorted him out. Since he thinks I'm a dim-witted ignoramus, he probably expected nothing better from me and settled for my little lie.</paragraph> <newpage/>

<paragraph>Mr. Chamberlain Ulrich was here again, but this time he did not come to quarrel with me, but on the contrary came running with a plea. His stomach is bothering him. After a short examination I immediately knew that he was suffering from a stomach ulcer, but I had not forgotten the unprecedented humiliation he had caused me, so instead of a professional diagnosis, I muttered something about Galen and the body fluids, threw up my hands helplessly and escorted him out. natroskach_zapiskyfelcara_wvD0: <paragraph>Commodore Ulrich was here again, this time quite unpleasant and threatening. He said that if I couldn't deal with his problem, I had no business on the Ruins. I told him that his problem was quite rare (which obviously flattered him) and that I could only treat common ailments. His problem would need a real doctor. And since I flattered him and made a fool of myself, he was satisfied with my explanation.</paragraph><paragraph> But he demanded that I recommend someone. I sent him to Cologne to see Professor Jáchym Bavorsky, who is known to be a rather eccentric astrologer. The meeting of these two figures will certainly be amusing, I almost wish I could see it. </paragraph><paragraph>I cannot prolong the sufferings of this pompous snob indefinitely, however, it might not be worth it. Next time I'll make him my stomach concoction. Two handfuls of thistle, some nettle leaves and a little charcoal, which in small quantities is known to aid digestion, will do the trick.</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>Chamberlain Ulrich was here again, this time quite unpleasant and threatening. He said that if I couldn't deal with his problem, I have nothing to do at Trosky. I told him that his problem was quite rare (which obviously flattered him) and that I could only treat common ailments. His problem would need a real physician. And since I flattered him and made a fool of myself, he was satisfied with my explanation.</paragraph><paragraph> But he demanded that I recommend someone. I sent him to Kolin to see Professor Joachim Bavorsky, who is known to be a rather eccentric astrologer. The meeting of these two figures will certainly be amusing, I almost wish I could see it. </paragraph><paragraph>I cannot prolong the sufferings of this pompous snob indefinitely, however, as it might turn against me. papezskylegat_vavakletter_V5JC: <paragraph>If you're reading these lines, know that I'm long out of town. I know you, you sycophant, have had your eye on my job for a long time. poi_duelostrostrelcu_skil_eFGM: Since the time of Alexander the Great, the bow has been an obsolete weapon, unworthy of a thinking man. But this dumb, back-bending instrument of the limited can easily be improved by substituting the human arm with a wooden one!

Since the time of Alexander the Great, the bow has been an obsolete weapon, unworthy of a thinking man. But this dumb, back-bending instrument of the limited can easily be improved by substituting the human arm with a wooden one!
poi_duelostrostrelcu_skil_isuC: Ever since the times of Adam, the bow has been the accurate, swift, silent and deadly weapon of choice for true men. Only a coward with arms as weak as a babe would resort to another – slower and dishonourable – weapon.

Ever since the times of Adam, the bow has been the accurate, swift, silent and deadly weapon of choice for true men. Only a coward with arms as weak as a babe would resort to another weapon – slower and dishonourable.
poi_indianajonespoem_part_EB2c:
From two magical hills looking up into the sky,
Like a thirsty pilgrim I take the path.
Across the valley overgrown to the edge of the earth,
There I will drink from the spring that will not let me perish.

From two magical peaks, that gaze into the heavens,
Like a thirsty pilgrim I set out upon the path.
Across a valley overgrown to the very edge of the earth,
There I shall drink from a spring that will not let me perish.

poustevnik_edictorderambr_hFyw: <paragraph><inc>O</inc>f the year of our Lord 1382, we make it known to all before God that Brother Ambrose of Prague has fulfilled his vows of order and mastery, and has attained considerable renown and skill in his work, as well as having attained due wisdom in his age. We hereby place in the hands of Brother Ambrose of Prague all the duties and dignity of the office of Seneschal of the Order and swear allegiance to him before God. Our Brother is further dispensed from the hospital service and is charged with the care of appointing honest correctors of the courts and confirming suitable preceptors of castles, hospitals and other residences of the Order.</paragraph><paragraph>For his own use and that of his office, apart from the ordinary customs, our elder Brother Ambrose is given two good riding horses and one each for his knight and chaplain. He is also to have the service of one archer and two squires in armour, as well as two servants under saddle.</paragraph>

poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_B1nK: <paragraph>I buried my friend Ambrose on the edge of the meadow above his hut. I piled stones by two gnarled birches and then marked the grave with a broken sword. Let whoever passes by take it, it doesn't matter anymore.</paragraph>

poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_bjr0: <heading> Quintilis 1403</heading><paragraph> My God, how could you let this happen? Why did Satan come among us? Why can't brother trust brother? The Inquisition has Grandmaster Zdenek in its grasp! When he found out what I knew, he wanted to kill me.... God forgive me, I killed my brothers!</paragraph><paragraph>...The only one who can stop Zdenek is my old friend Ambrose. He's been living in seclusion for a long time, but he still has the rank of seneschal. Only he can convict Zdenek and save our order.</paragraph><newpage/>

poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_j0yU: <heading>February 1403</heading><paragraph>Omnia mentiunt, but now I know for sure that Mark was hiding from the Inquisition in Maria Kulm! I searched for relatives and found that, coincidentally, Waldemar's nephew Kolda was released from the bishop's prison a month later. Someone had put in a good word for him.</paragraph><paragraph>... poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_J8Iq: <heading>December 1402</heading><paragraph>Younger Brother Mark was an able monastic apothecary in our Prague Commandery, but in the spring he is said to have become involved with the Inquisition. Other brothers later helped him escape from the city to the countryside</paragraph><paragraph>.... Qui bono? Why did the Inquisition go after Mark? ... what did the priest Waldemar have to do with it?</paragraph><paragraph>I must question their relatives!</paragraph><newpage/>

poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_KMJd: <heading>April 1403</heading><paragraph>Brother Mark was involved in a heinous murder! Last spring, the Inquisition forced him to poison the Archbishop of Prague, Albram! Afterwards, they wanted to get rid of Marek, but he disappeared in time. Little did he know that the old priest Waldemar would turn him in for the life of his nephew Kolda. The Inquisition eventually got rid of both brothers and made it look like a diabolical rampage.</paragraph><paragraph>... Who all is involved? The intrigue runs high! I have to tell my Grandmaster Zdenek about everything!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Aprilis 1403</heading><paragraph>Brother Mark was involved in a heinous murder! Last spring, the Inquisition forced him to poison the archbishop of Prague, Olbram! Afterwards, they wanted to get rid of Mark, but he disappeared in time. Little did he know that the old priest Waldemar would turn him in for the life of his nephew Kolda. The Inquisition eventually got rid of both brothers and made it look like a devilish rampage.</paragraph><paragraph>... Who all is involved? The intrigue runs high! poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_n78p: <heading>Novembris 1402</heading><paragraph>On my way from Cheb to Prague, I was caught by a message from the provost of Konigsberg about the terrible murder of two brothers of the order. The murder happened two days ago in the nearby Maria Kulm Commandery. The two unfortunates were found flogged in the sacristy of the church. The elder priest Waldemar died in horror, tied to the rump of a black goat with Brother Mark's limb stuck deep in his mouth. Mark's fingers had been broken and his head smashed to a pulp. The superstitious villagers consider this to be the work of the devil, but this is a simple premeditated murder of our brothers!

poustevnik_konraddiary_pa_XRP7: <heading>Quintilis 1403</heading><paragraph>The amber is dead. Mors ultima linea rerum. I arrived at night at the Troskovice rocks and found my friend sick to death. He no longer perceived me, but awoke in the morning and suddenly spoke clearly. I gave him absolution, and a little while later he let his soul out</paragraph><paragraph>... God, you have already taken everything I had, at least grant me to fulfill his last wish. Give me the strength to find a way to save sinful souls. Ex nihilo nihil fit.</paragraph><paragraph>... please Lord show me the way!</paragraph><newpage/>

poustevnik_oldorderpapera_4PfO: <heading>About the death of Blessed Agnes of Premyslid</heading><paragraph>After the severe winter of the summer of 1282, under the administration of the fourth Grand Master, who was Otto of Saxony, died the venerable abbess, the Most Holy Agnes of the Přemysl family, called Bohemian, who founded the Order of the Crusaders and contributed most to its flourishing. This woman, in her holy work, never married, although many princes aspired to her, and on the contrary she dedicated her life to God. Together with other noble maidens she founded the Convent of the Poor Virgins of St. Clare and became its first abbess. Here she cared for the poor and the sick and, as a daughter of the king, sought to right wrongs, always protecting the poor from the strong and powerful. Kyrie, eleison.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About the death of Blessed Agnes of Premyslid</heading><paragraph>After the severe winter in the year of the Lord 1282, under the administration of the fourth Grand Master, who was Otto of Saxony, died the venerable abbess, the Most Holy Agnes of the Premyslid family, called Bohemian, who founded the Order of the Knights of the Cross and contributed most to its flourishing. This woman, in her holy work, never married, although many princes aspired to her, and on the contrary she dedicated her life to God. Together with other noble maidens she founded the Convent of the Poor Virgins of St. Clare and became its first abbess. Here she cared for the poor and the sick and, as a daughter of the king, sought to right wrongs, always protecting the poor from the strong and powerful. Kyrie, eleison.</paragraph><newpage/>
poustevnik_oldorderpapera_cY5k: <heading>On the Fire of the Order's Commandery</heading><paragraph>The death of the blessed Emperor Charles IV in the summer of Lord 1378 ignited a spark of sinful hatred. Only a few hours after the death of the illustrious emperor, a red rooster engulfed the entire Order's commandery in the Old Town of Prague. The flames quickly consumed the entire church, the hospital and the Order's library containing thousands of precious manuscripts and holy relics. Many of the sick and the brothers who had thrown themselves into the fire for them were burned.</paragraph><paragraph>The terrible loss was all the greater because the land books and records also disappeared. It was very well contrived. For the new pope, Urban VI, did not look kindly on rich monasteries and rebellious orders, and gave his bishops free rein to intrigue. Much of the order's property was soon lost under strange circumstances.</paragraph><paragraph>Old Grand Master Frederick died two years later and could no longer look on at the misdeeds of his brothers. His successor was elected Zdeněk, who, however, more than concerned with the reformation of things, was on the contrary more concerned with intrigue, and conspired with the Prague chapter against the archbishop, so that truth and unity came to a great detriment. God, what dark times have come for our order. We have fallen prey to the whore of Babylon and have been poisoned by the poison from her breast. For by courtesy small things grow, but by discord even the greatest things crumble to dust.</paragraph><newpage/>

poustevnik_oldorderpapera_D3cq: <heading>About Judith's Bridge</heading><paragraph>Blessed Daniel, the thirteenth Bishop of Prague, had the intention of building a stone bridge where for centuries only deep fords and sandy huts led across the Vltava River. The bishop also won his king Vladislav II for his idea. Premyslid and his wife Judith, when they were in Italy on a campaign against the Milanese in the summer of 1158 and took great booty there.</paragraph><paragraph>The bishop also enlisted excellent Italian craftsmen to build Prague's oldest bridge, so that it was said to have been built in just three years, so that it was possible to cross between the Old Town on the eastern bank to the sub-castle of the old Premyslid kings' seat on the west. Named Judith's Bridge after the noble patroness of the building, it became the oldest in the Bohemian Kingdom and the third stone bridge north of the Alps before the terrible flood of the summer of Lord 1342 destroyed it.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About Judith's Bridge</heading><paragraph>Blessed Daniel, the thirteenth Bishop of Prague, had the intention of building a stone bridge where for centuries only deep fords and sandy paths led across the Vltava River. The bishop also won his king Vladislav II Premyslide and his wife Judith, when they were in Italy on a campaign against the Milanese in the summer of 1158 and took a great wealth there.</paragraph><newpage/>The bishop also enlisted excellent Italian craftsmen to build Prague's oldest bridge, so that it was said to have been built in just three years, so that it was possible to cross between the Old Town on the eastern bank to the sub-castle of the old Premyslid kings' seat on the west. Named Judith's Bridge after the noble patroness of the building, it became the oldest in the Bohemian Kingdom and the third stone bridge north of the Alps before the terrible flood in the year of the Lord 1342 destroyed it.</paragraph><newpage/>
poustevnik_oldorderpapera_eNwQ: <heading>About the founding of the Knights of the Cross</heading><paragraph>There have always been many foreign religious orders in the Kingdom of Bohemia, but none of our roots have ever come from them. The blessed daughter of Přemysl, Agnes of Bohemia, seeing the misery and suffering of her subjects, who, plagued by sickness and wounds, had nowhere to turn, founded in the year 1233, at her female monastery, the humble hospital brotherhood of St. Francis.</paragraph><paragraph>By the grace of God, unity and devotion to helping their fellow men, the brothers soon achieved renown, so that after only two years the brotherhood moved to the church of St. Peter under the old town of Vyšehrad in Prague. Many clerics and priests now came with an interest in joining the Order, which was not even a real Order yet. In the year of the Lord 1237, through the intercession of the blessed Agnes of Bohemia, Pope Gregory IX himself took the Hospitallers under his protection, so that no foreign power could harm them and they would have to confess to him and to God alone. The Bull Omnipotens Deus established the brotherhood as the Knights of the Cross.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About the founding of the Knights of the Cross</heading><paragraph>There have always been many foreign religious orders in the Kingdom of Bohemia, but none of them have ever come from our roots. The blessed daughter of Premysl, Agnes of Bohemia, seeing the misery and suffering of her subjects, who, plagued by sickness and wounds, had nowhere to turn, founded in the year 1233, at her nunnery, the humble hospital brotherhood of St. Francis. By the grace of God, unity and devotion to helping their fellow men, the brothers soon achieved renown, so that after only two years the brotherhood moved to the church of St. Peter under the old town of Vyšehrad in Prague. Many clerics and priests now came with an interest in joining the Order, which was not even a real Order yet. </paragraph><paragraph>In the year of the Lord 1237, through the intercession of the blessed Agnes of Bohemia, Pope Gregory IX himself took the Hospitallers under his protection, so that no foreign power could harm them and they would have to confess to him and to God alone. The Bull Omnipotens Deus established the brotherhood as the Knights of the Cross.</paragraph><newpage/>

poustevnik_oldorderpapera_L76z: <heading>On the flowering of the Order</heading><paragraph>The Crusader Order stood faithfully by the Přemyslid family for many years, and for this it received many benefits. But when King Wenceslaus III was assassinated in Olomouc in the summer of 1306, the country was in a terrible state of limbo for five years. Then the Crusaders fortified their commands, but not their hearts. Many pilgrims continued to find relief from illness within the walls of the hospitals. Finally, the turmoil was ended by the coronation of the new King John of Luxembourg.</paragraph><paragraph>The Crusaders did well in his service, but it was his son, Emperor Charles IV, who brought the order to its true flowering. Thanks to him, the order acquired a wealth of learned foreign books, holy relics and other mysteries. The Order's commanderies abounded from Cheb to Vratislava in Silesia, and many villages, mills, ponds and castles fell under the sovereign power of the God-fearing Grand Master Fridrich.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>On the growth of the Order</heading><paragraph>The Crusader Order stood faithfully by the Premyslid family for many years, and for this it received many benefits. But when King Wenceslas III was assassinated in Olomouc in the year of the Lord 1306, the country was in a terrible state of lawlessness for five years. Then the Order of the Cross fortified their commandery, but not their hearts. Many pilgrims continued to find relief from illness within the walls of the hospitals. Finally, the turmoil was ended by the coronation of the new King John of Luxembourg.</paragraph><paragraph>The Order did well in his service, but it was his son, Emperor Charles IV, who brought the order to its true growth. Thanks to him, the order acquired a wealth of learned foreign books, holy relics and other mysteries. The Order's commanderies abounded from Cheb to Vratislava in Silesia, and many villages, mills, ponds and castles fell under the sovereign power of the Grand Master Frederick.</paragraph><newpage/>
poustevnik_oldorderpapera_O5c2: <heading>About the founding of the hospital in the Old Town of Prague</heading><paragraph>In the summer of 1252, under the second Grand Master Conrad called Swabian, because he came from Swabia, the brothers moved to the foot of the Judith Bridge and founded a new large hospital there. In addition to caring for the wounded and sick, the Order was given the privilege by the gracious King Wenceslas I to collect customs duties on the bridge for its repairs.</paragraph><newpage/><paragraph>The new hospital with the Church of the Holy Spirit soon became the main seat of the Order, which flourished greatly in those blessed years thanks to the beneficence of the King and other Bohemian lords. They thought of their immortal souls by having other hospitals built in their towns for the greater glory of God.</paragraph><newpage/>

pracharna_diaryrecordofba_ty0P: Dear ruler of the chambers. Persevere. We shall soon escape the dungeon of those two women. But as the remnants of my age left my body for the last time, something else washed up with them.

Dear Mistress of the chambers. Persevere.
We shall soon escape the dungeon of those two women.
Cursed fate, however, has placed an obstacle in my way.
The heat of the Lightbringer's potion is working, and I can feel my insides being reborn.
But when the last remnants of old age left my body, something else was washed away with them.
My damned clumsiness. It has sent all of the Lightbringer's secrets into the void.
But fear not. I shall get them back.
May this be the first task on the road to your liberation.

q_book_lore_basne_2:
Gentle night, why linger on?
I yearn thus for my love so long,
Without her words to calm my breast,
Who shall set my soul to rest?

And now my heart in sorrow dwells,
From melancholic pining swells.
Since I, alas, was forced to part
From the mistress of my heart.

Ah Lord, let me not wait in vain,
I yearn to see my love again!
Oh gentle Sir, be of good cheer,
I shall not cling to another, dear.

q_book_lore_basne_3:
To love and be forlorn
Is like night without a dawn.
To be close with nought to say,
Like winter frost in May.

To have lips and yet kiss not,
Is like leaving grain to rot,
To love without consumating
Is like unsown fields in the spring.

I shall love you then, my dear
As long as you lie with me here.
If you'll not give your all to me,
No longer shall I bide with thee.

q_book_lore_proti_blecham_II: <inc>S</inc>cabies and growths of the skin of all manner, the same as insects and all low, crawling creatures, have been the bane of mankind since time immemorial. For he who wishes to protect his body, he must sleep less amongst cattle, at least once a fortnight wash himself in water or visit a bath, and expose his clothes to the sun. For water and sun drive away all ailments of the skin, whilst sickness does flourish where there is the filth and stench of the human body. Keep distance from vagrants and beggars, for it is they who are the greatest bearers of illness and they can easily infect you.<newpage/>

q_book_lore_rukopis_kralovedvor_2:
Breezes waft through princely woods,
A maiden hurries to the stream
To draw water in an iron-hooped pail.

To the girl a bouquet floats,
A fragrant bouquet of violets and roses.
And when she reaches for the bouquet,
She falls, alas, in the water cold.

“If I only knew, bouquet so fair,
Who sowed you in the fertile soil,
I'd give a golden ring to him.

If I only knew, bouquet so fair,
Who bound you with a silky stem,
I would give him the very pin from my hair.

If I only knew, bouquet so fair,
Who dropped you in the water cold,
I would give him the wreath from my head.

rozinakniha_cleverparson__d3fb:
<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is not knowing</subtitle>
<paragraph>A certain Kutnohora grandee once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, "I see you are the father of two children..." "That's what you think," shook his head. "I am the father of three children!" "That's what you think..." smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle>
<paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
rozinakniha_cleverparson__GtEp: A book of short stories secretly written in Mrs. Rosa's hand. The last part is our work together.
A book of short stories secretly written in Lady Rosa's hand. The last part is our work together.
rozinakniha_cleverparson__lz4a: About the clever parson One priest in Prague didn't like the fact that his parishioners didn't want to buy indulgences. The treasury in the church was empty, but some really wealthy people were coming to confession, and the priest knew they had something to confess. So one day, as the people were gathering to leave after Mass, he announced, so that everyone could hear: "Good people! Believe me, I am very reluctant to do this, but I must. Hear that there is a man among us who is having a sinful affair with his neighbor's wife. Remember the sixth commandment - thou shalt not commit adultery! - and listen to me well. If there are not at least one hundred and twenty groschen in the treasury by tomorrow evening, I will publicly proclaim who the sinner is among us." The parishioners dispersed to their homes, whispering excitedly among themselves as to whom the parson could possibly be talking about. The latter only smiled under his beard, looking forward to seeing how he would succeed with his threat. When he opened the treasury the next evening, he found not one hundred and twenty, but the whole three hundred groschen, and a small folded note with the following message: "Have mercy, father, and give me one more day. I'll get the other sixty somewhere!"

About the clever priest One priest in Prague didn't like the fact that his parishioners didn't want to buy indulgences. The treasury in the church was empty, but even some really wealthy people were coming to confession, and the priest knew they had something to confess. So one day, as the people were gathering to leave after Mass, he announced, so that everyone could hear: 'Good people! Believe me, I am very reluctant to do this, but I must. Hear that there is a man among us who is having a sinful affair with his neighbor's wife. Remember the seventh commandment - thou shalt not commit adultery! - and listen to me well. If there are not at least one hundred and twenty groschen in the treasury by tomorrow evening, I will publicly proclaim who the sinner is among us.' The parishioners dispersed to their homes, whispering excitedly among themselves as to whom the priest could possibly be talking about. The latter only smiled under his beard, looking forward to seeing how he would succeed with his threat. When he opened the treasury the next evening, he found not one hundred and twenty, but the whole three hundred groschen, and a small folded note with the following message: 'Have mercy, father, and give me one more day. I'll get the other sixty somewhere!'

rozinakniha_cleverparson__Rg1W:
<newpage/><heading>What's up, Adam's family</heading>
<subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle>
<paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two generations, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?
<paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgment and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate, and have made this judgment an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph>
<paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph>
<paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph>
<paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading>
<subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle>

rozinakniha_clumsyseamstr_S6ut:
<newpage/><heading>What's up, Adam's family</heading>
<subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle>
<paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two generations, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?
<paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgment and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate, and have made this judgment an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph>
<paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph>
<paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph>
<paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!

rozinakniha_clumsyseamstr_VBhq: About the Vengeful Seamstress Not so long ago, a young seamstress used to have her own shop in Kutná Hora. A young nobleman regularly had his clothes made by her. He was always kind, brought her gifts, spared no praise and the seamstress liked him. Once he asked her to make him a coat and trousers in which he could propose to his beloved. The seamstress got all flushed and asked if he knew the girl. He smiled and said he didn't, but if she made the dress, he would surely know her soon. The seamstress cheered inwardly and promised that the dress would be ready in three days. She chose the best cloth, worked day and night, and took care of every stitch. When on the third day the nobleman came to collect the finished dress, she was as good as new. "You have golden hands," the young man complimented her. "I will go at once to my sweetheart and ask for her hand! When she says yes, I'll bring her here to make her a dress for her wedding!" The seamstress recognized that the nobleman had taken advantage of her, and she felt like crying. But she made no sign of it, and as she helped the young man out of his coat, she tore one of the sleeves. "Oh, I am clumsy!" She apologized. "You can't stand up for your sweetheart like that! Give me another day and I'll fix the coat!" The young man didn't want to wait any longer, but he agreed rather than ask the lady for her hand in a torn dress. The seamstress had ripped out all the seams overnight and sewn in fleas she had picked up from a stray dog. She finished the job by pouring several generous handfuls of salt into the folds of fabric. The next morning, the nobleman picked up the dress and immediately rushed to his mistress in it. Soon, however, fleas came out of the seams and began to bite him. The young man scratched and clawed, but only rubbed the pungent salt into the fresh bites. He wriggled, jumped, stumbled about, and before he reached his sweetheart's house the whole town was laughing at him.

rozinakniha_eloquentdame__b5Jc: About a loquacious lady and a bad dancer It is known that anyone can point out someone's shortcomings and bring shame upon them. But few can point out someone's faults in such a way that the unfortunate person notices them without causing public ridicule. I will tell you of a lady who mastered this art. She was not only clever and quick in speech, but also young and beautiful to look at. When she appeared in society, men flocked to her. The young men asked her to dance and offered their arms, the older ones asked for her hand in marriage and offered what little the old men could still give to the young lady. Suddenly a young man asked her to dance. He had a handsome face and fine manners, so the lady accepted his proposal. After a few steps, however, she realized that she had made a big mistake. The dancer seemed to have two left feet. He stumbled, tripped, almost fell several times, and despite his apologies, the lady found dancing with him a torture. The other dancers noticed this, and began to whisper and point in their direction. Any other would have embarrassed him with indiscriminate words. She might even have sued the other ladies to watch out for the losers. Not the lady in my story. What does it matter if he's a bad dancer? she said to herself. Others may dance with ease, but they also drink with it, indulge in dice and light girls. Better a bad dancer than a good drinker. So she smiled and said out loud for all to hear, "Young sir, how I would love to keep dancing with you. But I wore the wrong shoes today. They're pushing me so hard that I can't go on. Please escort me out into the fresh air." Her dancer quickly understood what she meant by that remark and hurriedly walked with her to the door. Everyone present thought that perhaps she was going to give him a hard time at the door, or give him a well-deserved slap. The lady and her dancer, however, did not return to the entertainment that evening.

rozinakniha_girlwithgolde_apDr: About a black-eyed girl Once upon a time there was a poor girl. Black-eyed and black-haired, the most beautiful girl in the neighborhood, though she wore poor clothes and lived in a shack by the woods. The girls shunned her because they envied her beauty, but she made nothing of them. There was a miller in the village who thought of marrying her. He tried to flatter her with sweet words and told her what she would have if she became his wife. But she would not listen to his words. Soon word spread in the village that the miller was going to see her, and the rest of the girls became jealous. They came to the miller and each tried to tell him something bad about the black-eyed woman. She's a savage, a witch, the daughter of a urchin... The miller pretended to listen attentively, but subtly took something from each of them. One an embroidered ribbon, another a silver ring, the third a silk scarf. Then he hurried to the woods and gave the stolen items to the girl as a gift. He hoped to win her over and make her his wife at last. The black-eyed girl gratefully accepted the gifts, but when he proposed again, she again refused. The miller became angry, took her by the hand and dragged her to the stream where the other girls were washing clothes. "I'm bringing you a thief! Look what she took from you! Your scarf, your ribbon, even your ring!" Each of them recognized some of her belongings and in a fit of rage, they killed the black-eyed girl. When they realized what they had done, they begged the miller to help them. He promised to say nothing and buried the girl's body under a dead hazel bush. Because she lived away from the village, no one looked for her for a long time, and the miller thought that everything would be forgotten. In the spring, however, the hazel bush turned green and new twigs grew on it. When they grew stronger, the local shepherds made whistles out of them. But when they wanted to play, the whistles complained: Black eyes, white bones, Lies in the grave of a sweet girl. The miller stole, the miller lied, and buried her here himself... And so the young miller was betrayed and executed within a year of his crime.

The Black-eyed Girl Once upon a time there was a poor girl, black-eyed and black-haired, the most beautiful girl in those parts, though she wore poor clothes and lived in a shack by the woods. The other girls shunned her because they envied her beauty, but she ignored them. There was a miller in the village who thought of marrying her. He tried to flatter her with sweet words and told her what she would have if she became his wife. But she would not listen to his words. Soon word spread in the village that the miller was visiting her, and the rest of the girls became jealous. They came to the miller and each tried to tell him something bad about the black-eyed girl. She's a savage and a witch, they said. The miller pretended to listen attentively, but subtly took something from each of them. From one an embroidered ribbon, another a silver ring, the third a silk scarf. Then he hurried to the woods and gave the stolen items to the girl as a gift. He hoped to win her over and make her his wife at last. The black-eyed girl gratefully accepted the gifts, but when he proposed again, she again refused. The miller became angry, took her by the hand and dragged her to the stream where the other girls were washing clothes. 'I'm bringing you a thief! Look what she took from you! Your scarf, your ribbon, even your ring!' Each of them recognised her belongings and in a fit of rage, they killed the black-eyed girl. When they realized what they had done, they begged the miller to help them. He promised to say nothing and buried the girl's body under a dead hazel bush. Because she lived away from the village, no one looked for her for a long time, and the miller thought that everything would be forgotten. In the spring, however, the hazel bush turned green and new branches grew on it. When they grew stronger, the local shepherds made whistles out of them. But when they wanted to play, the whistles lamented: Eyes of black and bones of white lie here buried out of sight. The miller stole, the miller lied, 'Twas for his deceit that she died. And so the young miller was exposed and executed within a year of his crime.

rozinakniha_huntsmanandbe_GW6Y: The Nightingale Maiden In a distant land, there lived a young prince who, during one of his hunting trips into the forest, heard a girl's voice, singing so beautifully that the songbirds ruffled their feathers in envy. The prince followed the voice and thought to himself, "When I find this singing maiden, I will take her with me and marry her. Everyone will envy me, because my wife will sing more beautifully than a nightingale!" He walked and walked until he came to a clearing where an old, tall willow tree stood. In its crown sat a lovely maiden, singing so beautifully that even the wind in the branches fell silent. The prince set aside his crossbow, so as not to frighten the girl, and called out: "Beautiful maiden, I am the prince of this kingdom, and I ask for your hand! Be my wife and live as a queen!" "I cannot be your wife," she replied. "I am not allowed to leave here. But if you care for me, come again tomorrow." The prince was unwilling to give up the girl, and the next day he set out to see her again. He brought with him a magnificent golden ring. "Come with me, beautiful maiden. I will love you forever, and you will want for nothing!" he pleaded. "I’ve already told you that I cannot," she repeated. "But if you care for me, you will come again tomorrow." The third time, the prince brought the girl a dress made from the finest silk. She liked it, but again repeated that she could not marry him, even so. And so the young prince went to the willow a fourth time, bringing with him a trio of woodcutters. "You will finally be my wife!" he said, and ordered the tree to be cut down. The maiden wept and begged in vain. The tree soon fell to the ground, and the prince thought he had won. But as soon as her foot touched the moss-covered earth, the girl turned into a small nightingale and instantly disappeared into the shadows of the forest. Love cannot be taken by force, and whoever tries will soon lose it.

rozinakniha_huntsmanandbe_vlLQ:
<newpage/><heading>What's up, Adam's family</heading>
<subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle>
<paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two generations, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?
<paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgment and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate, and have made this judgment an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph>
<paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore we may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph>
<paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph>
<paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!

rozinakniha_miserlytownsm_kfED: About the miserly townsman Rich doesn't necessarily make a person bad. While there are rich people who are greedy and selfish, they are certainly not all like that. The townsman our story is about, however, is one of the richest and most miserly who ever lived. But his name was also Hermann Knauser! Knauser was renowned in the town for his wealth, but his avarice was the talk of the region. He had the most beautiful house in the best quarter and liked to invite visitors who admired its decoration. When it came to entertaining, however, he gave them dry bread, lest they should eat of the delicacies he kept for himself. One day, a painter who had formerly also stayed at the royal court came to town. So to have him paint something for me would surely be the envy of all! thought Mr. Knauser, and the next day he invited the master to his house. He took him through the rooms, showing him the costly furniture, fabrics, and statuettes with which they were decorated. The painter watched everything, but said nothing. Finally, Mr. Knauser told him: "Master, you see that my house contains the best of all kinds of art. I have seen the works of various artists, and few things can surprise me yet, let alone make me pay for it. What do you think, master, can you paint something like this?" The master, who had long ago guessed Knauser's character, shook his head and replied: "I'm sure he did. I'll show you something that will make your head spin. But I'll need plenty of time, and I can't bear for the client to see the work unfinished. If you really want my painting, go away for a week, let me work in peace, and when you come back, I promise you will find a work like you've never seen before." Knauser didn't want to host the master for a week, but finally agreed and left. Instead of painting for a week, the master was accosted by his servants, gradually drinking the wine cellar and raiding the pantry. It was not until just before his departure that he picked up his brushes and paints. When the master returned seven days later, he found the house empty, eaten to the last crumb. Knauser ran to the room where the master was to paint his picture on the wall. There he found a hastily painted fat roast pig on a golden tray, with a golden apple between its lips.

The Miserly Burgher Being rich doesn't necessarily make a person bad. While there are rich people who are greedy and selfish, they are certainly not all like that. The burgher of our story is, however, is one of the richest and most miserly who ever lived. For his name was Hermann Knauser! Knauser was renowned in the town for his wealth, but his greed was the talk of the region. He had the most beautiful house in the best quarter and liked to invite visitors who admired its decoration. When it came to hospitality, however, he gave them dry bread, lest they should eat of the delicacies he kept for himself. One day, a painter who had formerly also stayed at the royal court came to town. 'So to have him paint something for me would certainly be the envy of all!' thought Knauser, and the next day he invited the master to his house. He took him through the rooms, showing him the costly furniture, fabrics and statuettes with which they were decorated. The painter examined everything, but said nothing. Finally, Knauser told him: 'Master, you see that my house contains the best of all kinds of art. I have seen the works of various artists, and few things can surprise me yet, let alone make me pay for it. What do you think, master, can you paint something like this?' The master, who had long ago guessed Knauser's character, shook his head and replied: 'I'm certain I can. I'll show you something that will make your head spin. But I'll need plenty of time, and I can't bear for the client to see the work unfinished. If you really want my painting, go away for a week, let me work in peace, and when you come back, I promise you will find a work like you've never seen before.' Knauser didn't want to host the master for a week, but finally agreed and left. Instead of painting for a week, the master had Knauser's servants wait on him hand and foot, gradually drinking dry the wine cellar and emptying the pantry. It was not until just before his departure that he picked up his brushes and paints. When Knauser returned seven days later, he found the house empty of stocks, eaten to the last crumb. He ran to the room where the master was to paint his picture on the wall. There he found a hastily painted fat roast pig on a golden platter, with a golden apple in its jaws.

rozinakniha_miserwhorosef_RzMG: About the miser who rose from the dead Once upon a time there was a man in Kutná Hora who was considered the biggest miser in town. He never dropped a coin to beggars or street hustlers, he never went to taverns or bathhouses. Even when he walked down the street with a lantern and someone wanted to burn a candle from him, he would not share lest he accidentally run out of light. Even thieves avoided his house because there was nothing to take. His servants had to work for a pittance, and were given hard bread and half a tankard of beer with their meals. But even that was not enough for the miser. He pondered and pondered until he figured out a way to keep all his servants hungry for at least one day. He consulted the apothecary, and in the morning, at the time he usually rose, his servants discovered him lying on his bed, pale, cold, as if dead. None of them suspected that their master was actually alive and hearing their every word. They washed his body and wrapped him in a shroud, as was proper. But then they began to rejoice and rejoice loudly. When, instead of mourning and fasting, the servants opened the larders and chambers, rolled out the casks of wine and began to feast, the false dead man decided to put a stop to their celebrations. He arose from his bed, and, still in the shroud of death, ran among them. But before he could say anything, one of his servants, by this time quite drunk, cried out, "Ghost!" and took him over the head with a jug. The master was dead on the spot, but it was three days and three nights before anyone called for a priest.

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading>
<subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle>
<paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph>
<paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph>
<paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph>
<paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph>
<paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is not knowing</subtitle>
<paragraph>A certain Kutnohora grandee once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, "I see you are the father of two children..." "That's what you think," shook his head. "I am the father of three children!" "That's what you think..." smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle>
<paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>

rozinakniha_oneleggedhero_Pg4Q: About the one-legged heron Once upon a time there was a cook. His name was Witzbold, and one afternoon he was preparing his master a heron for dinner. The bird was already roasted, and the cook was just cutting fresh bread to nibble on, when a little girl he was very fond of came into the kitchen. "Witzbold, what a smell!" she gushed. "That you'd give me a leg..." "I'm not giving you anything!" he protested. "That's a heron for our master!" "If you're so stingy, I'll be there tonight!" The maid retorted. The cook was mollified, gave the girl a heron's leg, and hurried to the dining hall with the rest of the roast. But the master immediately noticed that the bird was missing one leg. Witzbold called back and demanded an explanation. "My lord, herons have just one leg. And therefore one leg," Witzbold replied seriously. "What are you saying, cook? Do you take me for a fool?" the master fumed. "It is as I say, sir. If you want to see for yourself, I'll show you for yourself," the cook boasted. The gentleman, convinced that the cook was lying, agreed. The next morning they went together to the pond, where a whole flock of herons were sleeping by the banks. Their heads were tucked under their wings and they were actually standing on one leg. "So you see, sir, a bird is a leg," the cook pointed triumphantly. The gentleman, however, did not accept defeat. He put his hands to his mouth and exclaimed: "Shoo!" until all the herons flew to the sky. Clearly they both saw that they had two legs, like any other bird. "Well, chef? Are you still going to tell me they only have one leg?" frowned the master. "Oh no, sir," Witzbold defended himself. "But you didn't shout 'shoo' at dinner last night either. Had you done so, surely the other leg would have grown on the roast." It served the Lord's honor that he laughed heartily instead of thinking of punishment. Witzbold appreciated it and never again presented him with an incomplete dinner.

About the one-legged heron Once upon a time there was a cook. His name was Witzbold, and one afternoon he was preparing his master a heron for dinner. The bird was already roasted, and the cook was just cutting fresh bread to nibble on, when a maid he was very fond of came into the kitchen. 'Witzbold, what a smell!' she gushed. 'Would you give me a thigh...' 'I am not giving you anything!' he protested. 'That's a heron for our master!' 'If you're so stingy, I'll also be tonight!' the maid retorted. The cook was mollified, gave the girl a heron's leg, and hurried to the dining hall with the rest of the roast. But the master immediately noticed that the bird was missing one leg. He called Witzbold back and demanded an explanation. 'My lord, herons have just one leg. And therefore one thigh,' Witzbold replied seriously. 'What are you saying, cook? Do you take me for a fool?' the master fumed. 'It is as I say, Sir. If you want to see for yourself, I'll show you.' the cook boasted. The gentleman, convinced that the cook was lying, agreed. The next morning they went together to the pond, where a whole flock of herons were sleeping by the banks. Their heads were tucked under their wings and they were actually standing on one leg. 'So you see, Sir, one bird, one leg,' the cook pointed triumphantly. The gentleman, however, did not accept defeat. He put his hands to his mouth and shouted: 'Shoo!' until all the herons flew to the sky. Clearly they both saw that they had two legs, like any other bird. 'Well, cook? Are you still going to tell me they only have one leg?' frowned the master. 'Oh no, Sir,' Witzbold defended himself. 'But you didn't shout "shoo" at dinner last night either. Had you done so, certainly the other leg would have grown on the roast.' It served the Lord's honour that he laughed heartily instead of thinking of punishment. Witzbold appreciated it and never again presented him with an incomplete dinner.

rozinakniha_remarriedwido_IxcN: A widower who remarried Once upon a time there was a rich old burgher in Kutná Hora. He had been widowed long ago, but he was not so old that he wanted to live alone. So he married a maid who served him. She was a simple, poor girl, but prettier than any noblewoman and twice as clever. But the old widower did not know that. It was enough for him to enjoy the sight of his wife during the day, and once in a while to enjoy her in the evening. He had no idea that the girl had eyes for his young groom more than for him. So when her husband did not want to enjoy her in the evening, she hurried to the stables to see the groom who slept there. One day, however, she forgot that her husband had an important journey early in the morning. What a surprise it was to both husbands when the master entered the stable at dawn. Instead of a horse, he found a saddled groom and his own wife in the saddle. What a scream! The husband had put her on to the harlots and was about to go to the town crier to get justice. His wife, however, did not just give in. She stood in his way and said: "Before you go complaining about me, think. Have I ever been unkind to you? When you asked me to come to you for the evening to please you, did I ever refuse?" "Never," the old man admitted. "You always came to me as I asked." "Have I ever been stingy, unwilling, or cold to you? Have I refused to give you what you wanted from me?" "No," he repeated, more modestly now. "You always gave me everything I asked for." "So tell me, what was I supposed to do with what was left? Feed it to the pigs? Lock it in a chest and throw away the key? After all, isn't it better to please another man who loves me? It doesn't take away from what's rightfully yours." The lord felt ashamed at the words and had to admit that his wife was right and that Plümmel, the town clerk, still knows nothing of it.

A widower who remarried Once upon a time there was a rich old burgher in Kuttenberg. He had been widowed long ago, but he was not so old that he wanted to live alone. So he married a maid who served him. She was a simple, poor girl, but prettier than any noblewoman and twice as clever. But the old widower did not know that. It was enough for him to enjoy the sight of his wife during the day, and once in a while to enjoy her in the evening. He had no idea that the girl had eyes for his young groom more than for him. So when her husband did not want to enjoy her in the evening, she hurried to the stables to see the groom who slept there. One day, however, she forgot that her husband had an important journey early in the morning. What a surprise it was to both partners when the master entered the stable at dawn. Instead of a horse, he found a saddled groom and his own wife in the saddle. What a scream! The husband called her a harlot and was about to go to the town bailiff to get justice. His wife, however, did not just give in. She stood in his way and said: "Before you go complaining about me, think. Have I ever been unkind to you? When you asked me to come to you for the evening to please you, did I ever refuse?" "Never," the old man admitted. "You always came to me as I asked." "Have I ever been stingy, unwilling, or cold to you? Have I refused to give you what you wanted from me?" "No," he repeated, more modestly now. "You always gave me everything I asked for." "So tell me, what was I supposed to do with what was left? Feed it to the pigs? Lock it in a chest and throw away the key? After all, isn't it better to please another man who loves me? It doesn't take away from what's rightfully yours." The husband felt ashamed at the words and had to admit that his wife was right and to this day Plümmel, the town bailiff, still knows nothing of it.

starekosti_hostinaumrlcu__8AeV: <paragraph>At that time a plague was raging in the city and in the surrounding area, which was mowing people down by the hundreds. But the rich, convinced that their earthly power would protect them from the punishment of God, made nothing of the disease, and spent their days and nights in drinking, during which they overfed, fornicated, and committed other sins in abundance. But the fact that they did not care about the death of everyone around them did not mean that death did not care about them.</paragraph>

starekosti_song_1_part_TjME:
In a pub in the village square under an old oak tree
a lute and a lute is sounding, a drum is beating
♪ Now softly - now loudly the music plays ♪ people from all over the region are dancing.

The whistle blows and the lute starts. ♪ The skinny ones dance, even the fat ones ♪ And when the drum is struck properly love blossoms on the field of dance.

Underneath the oak tree in the tavern on the square
a whistle and a lute ring out, and drums boom out their share.
From far and wide, from all around,
folk come to dance to the merry sound.

The whistle is whistling, the lute ringing out,
folk are all dancing, the thin and the stout.
And while the drum is loudly booming,
among the dancers, love starts blooming.
starekosti_song_2_part_tr4T:
the little shoemaker at the forest used to play his pipe
♪ He used to feed the sheep, his heart was at peace ♪ But now he's off to battle, where there's a lot of noise. He'll fight for the King of Bohemia
He lost his flock long ago. Instead, he played his song to the soldiers. He wished only one thing - to return home. but the fall of Kreschak and with it the king.

In the fields by the woods a shepherd boy plays
on his pipe as his sheep quietly graze.
But now he has gone to fight for his king,
away in a far distant place.

His flock is long scattered with no one to lead them,
he plays now to soldiers instead.
To return to his pasture was his only dream,
But in Crécy now he lies dead.
starekosti_song_3_part_waGP:
carved from willow
my little whistle
♪ she plays it sweetly ♪ ♪ lying down and standing up ♪ ♪ Hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey! ♪
♪ two or three times she whistles ♪ hard whistle
and the sweet one jumps with happiness. How proud she is of me

My whistle carved from willow,
Ah, it's such a fine thing.
On it my sweetheart loves to blow,
lying down or standing.
Ey ey ey - lying down or standing!

She blows and then she blows again,
my little whistle goes hard,
my darling jumps for joy then.
She says I am her bard.
Ey ey ey - she says I am her bard!
starymistr_hadanka_part_0pAH:
Vineyard? In a town? To hell with it all! And yet it's here, so try some more…

By waters that gush, hear to explore

Sharpen your senses, lift your gaze,

Where shadows point in the sun's blaze.

You'll find us there - no trick, no stall!

A vineyard in the town? Strange, but who knows!
And yet there it is, quite nearby.
By the water that gushes, now listen and try
to keep your eyes open, so that you can tell
shortly after the midday bell,
you'll find us where the shadow goes.

tarasmura_contract_part_6hsO: <paragraph>The knight's service is rewarded with food and water, delivered every month to the shaft by the locals. So undertakes the parish priest Ryško from Stará Kutna.</paragraph>
<paragraph>The knight's service is rewarded with food and water, delivered every month to the shaft by the locals. So undertakes the parish priest Richard from Old Kutna.</paragraph>
tarasmura_contract_part_L2Pe: <paragraph>The honored lord Taras the Moth swears a knight's oath to guard the pit of hell in the mines of Stará Kutna and not to leave the mines while his service lasts.</paragraph><paragraph>The oath will only be broken by another knight who will shoulder the burden of repentance and arrive at the mines and become a new guard by his own oath.</paragraph><paragraph>Such a knight will then, under the same conditions, be the new guardian of hell, and the previous guardian will again see heaven and the love of God, and all his sins will be forgiven in the sight of the Lord.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The honourable Sir Taras Mura swears a knight's oath to guard the pit of hell in the mines of Old Kutna and not to leave the mines while his service lasts.</paragraph><paragraph>The oath will only be rescinded by another knight who will shoulder the burden of repentance and arrive at the mines and become a new guard by his own oath.</paragraph><paragraph>Such a knight will then, under the same conditions, be the new guard of hell, and the previous guardian will again see heaven and the love of God, and all his sins will be forgiven in the sight of the Lord.</paragraph>

tarasmura_diary2_part_cBSh: <paragraph>I'm cold. I had to dismantle some of the scaffolding to get firewood.</paragraph><paragraph>It's always cold in the mines, but there's a freezing draft coming from the shaft where I get my food now. The stench pouring from the pit leaves no doubt of the presence of hell.</paragraph><newpage><paragraph>I remain your humble servant, Lord, and beg for mercy for my sins.</paragraph><paragraph>I, Taras the Moth, am the shield of God.</paragraph>

tarasmura_diary4_part_p5Uv: In the darkness I hear weeping and gnashing of teeth. I can't hold them in much longer. The voices of demons scratch at my soul like swords at my helmet.I can't take off my armor. I am never safe. Lord, protect me! They're everywhere. I can smell their burnt flesh again. I don't want to become one of them. The demons of hell are always calling my name. It sounds like the trumpet of the Last Judgment.

troskovice_chronicle_part_199M:
A capite ad calcem - we want to celebrate Brad.
>Gloria in excelsis deo - we respect him.
Consumbstantialem Patri - He belongs among us!
>In nomine domini - the swift is our only one.
Qui locutus est per Prophetas - he will not leave us to the captors.
Kyrie Eleison - he can do everything!
Et apostolicam Ecclesiam - the just is always with us.
Dominus Deus Sabaoth - he has a lot of sense.
Benedicimus te - and how learned he is!

A capite ad calcem – we celebrate Brada to the helm.
Gloria in excelsis deo – for we esteem him so.
Consumbstantialem Patri – He belongs with us, truly!
In nomine domini – our bailiff one and only.
Qui locutus est per Prophetas – he won't leave us to the brigands' grasp.
Kyrie Eleison – he can handle all on his own!
Et apostolicam Ecclesiam – he is always fair to us, this man.
Dominus Deus Sabaoth – he is full of wisdom and growth.
Benedicimus te – and how learned he can be!
Et vitam venturi saeculi – he ensures we live happily.
troskovice_chronicle_part_6Rr9: <heading>Zdena under the Root</heading><paragraph>The summer of the year thirteen hundred and twenty-seven was eventful. Quam gravis aestas erat - it seems impossible to write it all down here. Fear then sank its claws especially into old Zdena, who has a cottage near the forest. Per unam noctem in mense Iulio - listen to all that has happened. Zdena went into the woods, but in the darkness she went astray, fell down the hill and remained wedged in the roots of a tree. Half the village went to look for the poor woman, but the root prisoner herself could not answer their call to Zdena. Timor illam vocem subripuit - it was not until the morning that the woman was freed.</paragraph><newpage/>

troskovice_chronicle_part_8uw9: <heading>Guests of the lord of Trosky</heading><paragraph>The lord of Trosky often organizes great dances and invites important guests from all around. These events might not be of interest to our people if the Chamberlain of Trosecky did not take advantage of the situation. O tanta aviditas in corde suo - Conrad is the name of a bad servant. He often lures his master's guests out of the castle to show them the surroundings, and on that occasion he extorts small gifts from the noble lords. Among other places, he leads the lords to a strange alley to show them the bloody tree and the tree of the hanged man and to amuse them with bloody stories. Conradus non est nostrum - only our crane does not show the guests.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Guests of the lord of Trosky</heading><paragraph>The lord of Trosky often organizes great dances and invites important guests from all around. Among other places, he leads the lords to a strange alley to show them the bloody tree and the tree of the hanged man and to amuse them with bloody stories. Conradus non est nostrum - only our rowan tree does not show the guests.</paragraph><newpage/>
troskovice_chronicle_part_diLc: <heading>A great recounting of the soil</heading><paragraph>The lord of the Troshechi gave orders to measure the soil in the spring, to increase the quantity of grain brought to him. Dominus noster justus est - he shall take six sacks of wheat. And after the fields had been measured, the young men were brought to the proper places where the manor's grain was, that they might receive a good cutting, and so remember their place until death. Verberas magnus erat - let us know these boys. Janek from the inn, Karel from the pigs, Ales from the carpenter's, Martin from Tachov, Simon from Hoňsobě, Petr the whistle, Matěj the curly-haired, and Olbram from Želejov, with whom, however, there is constant trouble, for he remembers his place badly even after repeated beatings!</paragraph><newpage/>

troskovice_chronicle_part_dLIH: <heading>The tree that bled</heading><paragraph>Troskovice witnessed terrible events when Brenek and Michal, two local shepherds, decided to cut down a tree in the meadow above Vidlak. Non fuit bona idea - half the village is angry with them now. The tree they chose to cut down is known for attracting lightning from far and wide to protect the good people, but it endangers the cattle in the pasture. Arbor inchoata cruentatur - Michael first struck the trunk with the axe. But no sooner had he raised the instrument to cut again, than red blood began to gush from the wound. The horrible phenomenon so frightened both men that they threw down their axes and fled home. The parish priest, who was summoned to the scene, did not declare the tree miraculous, but the locals know their own and believe that the tree will not allow evil things to happen to it or in its vicinity.</paragraph><newpage/>

troskovice_chronicle_part_h1I6: <heading>Margaret's Lovers</heading><paragraph>It is not for a decent man to judge another's love, but the circle of Margaret's lovers is already asking to be noticed. Illa femina multum viros amat - the brothers Martin and John had time to ask her. The woman, however, did not want to return the love of the brothers and chose another man for herself, thus causing immense grief to the brothers. Pax animae Johannis - John, in his distress, threw himself off the rock! The body of John, unrequited by love, lay under the rock between Troskovice and Tachov, and was buried outside the holy ground. Tristis erat frater eis - Martin then went to meet the world. The brother of the deceased left our country after a great mourning and is said to have become a member of a knightly order in foreign lands.</paragraph><newpage/>

troskovice_chronicle_part_JANB: <heading>Francek Bezočka</heading><paragraph>The young rooter, who settled in Apolena, had to come again among the honest people, because Francek, who was herding cattle on a farm, got into a cross with a bull. Taurus eum invasit - the bull can break his ouds. When the animal, enraged, rushed at the poor man, he wanted to hide in the crown of the miraculous tree, so that the tree, which does not allow evil, would protect him from the beast. But Francek, in his confusion, mistook the trees, and climbed up the oak instead of the miraculous tree. Magnum clamorem audivimus - then the real abomination happened! The bull knocked Franck down from the oak with one blow, his body was torn to pieces, and even his eye was gouged out with his horn. Although the oak is certainly not a miraculous tree, it brought Franck good luck, for he did not lose his life and returned to work after eight Sundays.</paragraph><newpage/>

troskovice_chronicle_part_JIRD: <heading>Spring in Troskovice</heading><paragraph>Like every spring, the most gracious and wise swift man, who is invited by the Beard, inspected the fields and the living creatures and made this record. Sicut lex iubet villico - let us begin with the cattle for milk. There are fewer cows but more oxen in Troskovice this year. We have nice and big goats and plenty of sows too. Thanks to the cottagers Tomáš and Šimek, we have the two biggest bulls in the whole region. Nunc de terra fama - let's count the ground under our feet. The fields are still in the same management, even the land above the inn has not changed its lord, because the wedding of Anča and Vasek was ruined when the father of the bride, in his drunkenness, called Vasek a fool who had sex with sheep.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Spring in Troskovice</heading><paragraph>Like every spring, the most gracious and wise swift man, who is invited by Brada, inspected the fields and the living creatures and made this record. troskovice_chronicle_part_LQYT: <heading>Vasek the hanged man</heading><paragraph>Death has shrouded our land with a dark cloud, for Vasek, the shepherd, was found hanged. O mors est atrox et inutilis - all Troskovice mourned for him. Vasek, who had spent his life alone, and perhaps only loved Anca from the tavern, was buried outside the holy ground, for he had taken his own life. Today, the shepherds have returned to the fatal meadow, but the hanged man's tree continues to be circumvented. We can only give thanks to Vasek for not choosing the tree commemorating the famous battle for his heinous act, although he committed it in its vicinity. He could not have harmed the reputation and weight of the precious tree in any way.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Vashek Hanged</heading><paragraph>Death has shrouded our land with a dark cloud, for Vashek, the shepherd, was found hanged. O mors est atrox et inutilis - all Troskovice mourned for him. troskovice_chronicle_part_mgdr: <title>Troskovice Chronicle</title><subtitle>as laid down by Bailiff Brada</subtitle><newpage/>
troskovice_chronicle_part_ygvc: <poem><accent>And if people only knew one thing about him - Fecit ordinem in regione ope clavi ferrei</accent></poem>
<poem><accent>And if people knew just one thing about him truly – Fecit ordinem in regione ope clavi ferrei</accent></poem>
troskovice_chronicle_part_yRZ1: <heading>About the Avenue of the Strange</heading><paragraph>God has breathed many beautiful places into our region, to make it fit for human life. Deus dedit nobis terram perfectam - Of one place I will now tell you. On a hill near the pond of Vidlák, there is an avenue of strange trees, consisting of oaks, cranes and birches. Quercus, Sorbus, Betula - under one a battle was fought. Raubritter Albrecht and his band are said to have been defeated here a hundred years ago, and the tree adorns the site of his death. The other tree is of simpler origin and reminds us of the border between the lands of Tachov and Želejov. Optima ad finem - let us also speak of another tree. The third of the trees provides protection from the storm, for it attracts lightning from all around. There are hundreds of similar places in this region, but next time we will tell about them, so as not to shame other countries.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About the Avenue of the Strange</heading><paragraph>God has breathed many beautiful places into our region, to make it fit for human life.
